stefanhoth.name: Stefan Hoth
stefanhoth.description: Stefan is living in Berlin and a developer of many traits. He has programmed everything from Backends in Java or PHP, Chrome Apps and web frontends to Android apps. As a co-organizer of the GDG Berlin he can embrace his interest in getting to know new technologies, languages and frameworks.

matthiasfriedrich.name: Matthias Friedrich
matthiasfriedrich.description: As Android user from the beginning, I started to develop for the platform with version 1.6 in 2009. Since then I'm following its progress very enthusiastically and worked on several applications, big and small, successful in the Play Store and as specialized customer solutions. During these years, I also co-founded the GDG Bremen and GDG Android Hamburg, gave several Android related talks and organized developer events around Google technologies in general.

janmonschke.name: Jan Monschke
janmonschke.description: Jan is frontend web developer from Berlin who focusses on building collaborative, multimedia web applications. He is always looking for new challenges on the web and since learning about the Web Audio API at JSconf.eu 2012 it is his new passion to create music-related web apps and experiments.

alexandersurma.name: Alexander Surma
alexandersurma.description: Alexander "surma" Surma is a Software Engineer for nuboLAB and Co-Lead of the GDG Berlin Golang.

jenskuehlers.name: Jens Kühlers
jenskuehlers.description: Jens Kuehlers is a Solutions Engineer on the Google Cloud Platform, with 7 years of Infrastructure and Cloud experience at Google.

melindaalbert.name: Melinda Albert
melindaalbert.description: Melinda Albert is a mobile app designer based in Berlin and specialised in high end mobile concepts and designs for iOS & Android apps. Melinda has worked as a user experience designer for various large companies such as Telekom AG, Axel-Springer, Zalando, ImmobilienScout24 and the german public bank Sparkasse. She shares her professional knowledge about mobile usability through workshops, in-house seminars, talks and publications. http://www.melinda-albert.de http://de.linkedin.com/pub/melinda-albert/30/4b7/682/ https://www.xing.com/profile/Melinda_Albert

sebatianopoggi.name: Sebastiano Poggi
sebatianopoggi.description: A self-taught and strong OSS believer who loves beautiful and simple UX and UI, where “less is more”, Sebastiano spends a big chunk of his spare time reading and writing about Android development. He also creates and maintains some FOSS apps and libraries, that span from the fun, smaller projects to the more serious (and, perhaps, useful) work.

danielebonaldo.name: Daniele Bonaldo
danielebonaldo.description: Daniele is an Android Software Craftsman at Novoda in London.

dannypreussler.name: Danny Preussler
dannypreussler.description: Danny is in charge of Android development at Groupon in Berlin. Before that he worked for companies like eBay and Alcatel. Danny writes and talks about android development or testing regularly.

tiffanyconroy.name: Tiffany Conroy
tiffanyconroy.description: Tiffany is a self-taught JavaScript programmer trained as an electrically engineer. Front-end developer and interaction designer, mostly. “theophani” on Github, Twitter, Flickr, SoundCloud … and everywhere else. JSConf EU co-curator, weareaweso.me creator, BerlinJS co-organizer.

leehambley.name: Lee Hambley
leehambley.description: I’m the founder of a successful consultancy company personally offering extensive experience with Ruby, PHP, Lua, and SQL (MySQL and PostgreSQL). Sometimes I work with JavaScript, C or Objective-C. I contribute heavily to open source. I’ve maintained Capistrano for the last few years; it’s the de-facto standard for deploying Ruby or Rails applications. I’m working hard with a couple of awesome people at making it work well for other projects too, you can watch us work.

benjaminweiss.name: Benjamin Weiss
benjaminweiss.description:
Benjamin is a Developer Programs Engineer at Google in London
Shortly after moving to Berlin he started organizing the local Android community.
He has been involved with several conferences as co-organizer and speaker.
During his day jobs he developed Android apps for various companies and organizations.
Further Benjamin is the developer and maintainer of the Crouton library for Android.

astridparamitamochtarram.name: Astrid Paramita Mochtarram
astridparamitamochtarram.description: Founder and CEO at twindly (http://twindly.com). M.Sc. in Digital Media, B.Eng in Informatics. AI/Recommender enthusiast, UX/UI designer. Traveller, storyteller, beauty addict, and food connoisseur.

anitajaszewska.name: Anita Jaszewska
anitajaszewska.description: I'm Ruby on rails Developer, interested in Internet of Things and travelling. I learned how to program from scratch by myself and decided that this is the career for me.

andreasschranzhofer.name: Andreas Schranzhofer
andreasschranzhofer.description: Andreas Schranzhofer is the Head of Mobile Engineering at GetYourGuide Deutschland GmbH. In this position, he is responsible for all mobile apps and appendant technologies. His focus is on creating lean, cross-platform architectures, that enable products to focus on the user experiences.

danieltruemper.name: Daniel Trümper
danieltruemper.description: I am working as professional Software developer at Retresco where we build search based applications. While mostly writing code in Python I have a history in Java and keep on learning and enjoying Clojure recently. I hold a diploma in Economics and Computer Science and am a happy father of almost two.

jonatanreiners.name: Jonatan Reiners
jonatanreiners.description: I am Software Developer at Priori Data, responsible for backend technologies working together with the data scientists on bringing their models to life. I love elegant solutions for complex problems. Always trying to convince my team to try awesome new stuff!

slots.title: Doors open, Registration, Snacks
slots.desc: Come in, get your swag and ready to code.

slots.title: Welcome & Introduction
slots.desc: Learn what we have prepared for you, where the rooms are and what else is imporatant to know.

slots.title: Installing Android Studio and the SDK
Polymer Code-Lab
slots.desc: Attend the Polymer Polyclinic to understand what all the fuzz is about with 'web components'.

slots.title: Polymer Code-Lab
slots.desc: Attend the Polymer Polyclinic to understand what all the fuzz is about with 'web components'.

slots.title: Polymer Code-Lab
slots.desc: Attend the Polymer Polyclinic to understand what all the fuzz is about with 'web components'.

slots.title: Polymer Code-Lab
slots.desc: Attend the Polymer Polyclinic to understand what all the fuzz is about with 'web components'.

slots.title: Go: Syntax Speedrun I
slots.desc:
Go has been getting more and more attention over the last few years.
If it has peaked your interest as well, here's your chance to learn
the basics and write your first Go program.

slots.title: Go: Syntax Speedrun II
slots.desc:
Go has been getting more and more attention over the last few years.
If it has peaked your interest as well, here's your chance to learn
the basics and write your first Go program.

slots.title: Go: Write all the Pixels
slots.desc:
Go has been getting more and more attention over the last few years.
If it has peaked your interest as well, here's your chance to learn
the basics and write your first Go program.

slots.title: Go: Write all the Pixels
slots.desc:
Go has been getting more and more attention over the last few years.
If it has peaked your interest as well, here's your chance to learn
the basics and write your first Go program.

slots.title: WELCOME! Doors open, Registration, Breakfast, Snacks
What's new in Android
slots.desc: Android 5.0 aka Lollipop has been released. This session will give an overview of the technologies and APIs included in this release.

slots.title: How to make your Mobile App outstanding?
slots.desc:
You have an android app and have you also followed Guidelines. How can you make sure, that your app doesn´t look all the other android apps alike, which also followed the Guidelines? How can you make your app stand out visually more in the Playstore? Melinda Albert is going to explain you in 40 minutes how you could bring more delightful details in your user interface, make your product more memorable so that it attracts new customers.

These are some of the questions which are included and going to be answered during the session: What are delightful details and how can we cluster them? Are colors and icons enought to create a brand identity? How can we achieve a visually memorable product that user remember and love?

slots.title: Android as it gets worn
slots.desc: One of Android's new shapes is the one of a watch on your wrist. Besides the basic adjustments of notifications for Wearable devices, it is also possible to run full-fledged applications (that don't suck) on their small screens. These applications are highly dependent on new APIs for inter-device communication and some new UI widgets. This talk gives an introduction to Android Wear, its special APIs, features and latest developments.

slots.title: AOSP building blocks
slots.desc: Most of us Android developers are able to build awesome apps, but do we really know how the Android OS works? In some cases, as when developing a new product, adding customised apps is not enough, and OS modifications are required. From downloading the source code, to where to touch and modify it, to the (technical) process for placing it on your device. We will explore the world of Google's Repo and its collection of git repositories. The attendees will be able to customize the Android OS to address the needs of a new product, editing some features normally hidden to normal apps.

slots.title: Framing the Canvas
slots.desc: This talk will guide you through a topic that is often ignored: the Canvas API. Even if there's only scarce documentation for it, the Canvas API is at the heart of everything that shows a UI on Android. You'll need to tame this powerful and mysterious creature if you want to create great custom views and brilliant, lightweight UIs for your apps. What is a Canvas? How do you Paint? Can you draw Paths? What is Skia, and who invited it anyway? What actualy happens during a drawing pass? What are Shaders? What are Filters? Is it true that text is basically impossible to measure correctly? What shape does a Shape have if noone's painting it? These and other questions will get an answer during this session. Well, some of them will not, probably. Connect the dots in the spotty documentation the Android team has assembled, and become a true pixel pusher!

slots.title: More Android Code Puzzles
slots.desc: After the 1st round at droidconNL 2012 this is the 2nd round in best tradition of Joshua Bloch’s Java puzzle talks. We will show code, audience try to guess what it does or maybe does not! Don’t get fooled, but they will try!

slots.title: Fireside chat with all speakers of the Android track
Using the web for music production and for live performances
slots.desc: The introduction of the Web Audio API has enriched the web landscape enormously. It gives game developers the ability to add precisely timed, high performant sound effects and to create realistic spatialized sound landscapes. For many web developers it is the first time they encounter audio programming which leads to many interesting experiments when the world of web and audio collide. Traditional web developers start to become really interested into audio programming and educate themselves on the topic of synthesizers and audio effects. However, currently there are only few applications that try to create audio production or audio performance environments in the browser. In this talk I want to show how the Web Audio API can be used to create a collaborative music production environment similar to Garageband. Furthermore, I will do a live demonstration of a music performance setup which is inspired by The Glitch Mob’s setup (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9bXNo9MFXnU). Both demos will show how powerful the Web Audio API is and how important the web can become as platform for music production in the future.

slots.title: Introduction into Polymer
slots.desc: A frame work for web applications based on web components made by Google.

slots.title: Lions and tigers and handling user capabilities
slots.desc: Many applications restrict access to some features for some users for various reasons. For example: Only premium users get access to extra features. Only supervisors can edit product categories. I went on a hunt to gather patterns and techniques for handling the logic around user capabilities in client-side apps. Join me on a safari through the approaches, and I’ll tell you what I have learned.

slots.title: Using Padrino - An introduction into a simple Ruby framework
slots.desc: Everyone who is into web development knows Rails. It is indeed powerful framework based on Ruby, but what about people who need to build something small and quick? Padrino might be the answer.

slots.title: App Indexing for Google Search
slots.desc: At GetYourGuide we went live with the App-Indexing just a few weeks ago. We support deeplinking of almost all webcontent into the app. In order to be able to do that, we implemented a sophisticated deeplinking scheme. This scheme can accept any kind of query that we could also trigger through our API. As a result, it is very straightforward to automatically create the Andrdoid (and iOS) deeplink for any content on our webpage. Our talk would start with how this deeplinking was set up and how it connects to web content. Since Google is very picky that App-Indexes provide exactly the same content as the corresponding Webpage, it is very important to have this mapping set up correctly. Since this went live we also had to add support for the Google Crawler, both on the API but also in the App. We were not really aware of that and got our tracking skewed (ie., most of our traffic was from Mountain View for a while). The second part of the talk would be about how handle these things. How to identify legit traffic and ignore crawler traffic in your tracking. This is particularly important for eCommerce companies like ourselves.

slots.title: Visual Regression Testing
slots.desc: CSS can often be really frustrating when changing small parts create unwanted changes in several areas of our web application. There are several approaches to prevent this. One is writing highly modularised and object orientated CSS (also known as OOCSS). But often we don't work in a perfect world like this. Therefor more and more people getting interested in Visual Regression Tests. By taking and comparing screenshots of our web app on regularly basis we have the chance to catch every visual bug that occurs. These tests require an highly automated process to be able to deploy it in our continuos integration circle. Tools like PhantomCSS or WebdriverCSS made this more and more easy to do with less flakiness and frustration. This talk will give you insights about how to write visual regression tests with WebdriverCSS in an scaleable cloud environment using Sauce Labs and Applitools. It will point out some best practices and will demonstrate how to integrate it in your CI process.

slots.title: Fireside chat with all speakers of the Web track
Using Google Cloud Infrastructure for twindly: A Social Recommender Platform
slots.desc:
In this session, we will talk about our architecture goal and the steps we go through to approach and build it. What are the moving parts we get to play around with:
- Hosting + compute: App Engine and Compute Engine - Storage: Cloud Datastore - Big Data: BigQuery - Prediction API Most importantly, lessons learned during the process of learning and breaking things, everthing is work in progress!

slots.title: Elasticsearch, Twitter and some news
slots.desc: After a short introduction to Elasticsearch we will index Tweets that contain URLs to articles on news sites. With the help of retweets and the original tweet date we can create a hacker news style ranking of news. With some minor tweaking at index time we will be able to create views for todays "top news", top news per publisher and top users contributing to the site. With sharding, replication and time slicing I will discuss ES's scaling capabilities. Also recent discussions around it's consistency and dataloss will be mentioned shortly.

slots.title: Transactional HTTP Tests With Go’s Standard Library
slots.desc: Kitchen-sink frameworks such as Rails include massive amounts of code designed to help with easy out of the box testing through the whole stack. In this talk I’ll discuss the tooling I came up with to emulate the good parts of the Rails database migrations, and transactional tests and fixtures fixtures using some of Go’s excellent standard library.

slots.title: DataScience with BigQuery.
slots.desc: * Introduction in Company and the challenges inherent. * Why we choose BigQuery. * Data pipeline and tools. * Create queries and why it is important to understand how BigQuery works. * 2 Types of Models realized in BigQuery Moving to the caching layer * limitations of BigQuery * Utilize the data in our web application

slots.title: Containers and Kubernetes
slots.desc: In this session I will go over the history of containers at Google, what we have done internally, how containers differ from VM and what they are good for and what Kubernetes is. I will then show a quick demo of how to bring up a Kubernetes cluster on the Google Cloud Platform and how to deploy a simple service. I will also show the self healing mechanisms of Kubernetes.

slots.title: Fireside chat with all speakers of the Cloud track
Doors open, Registration, Snacks
slots.desc: Come in, get your swag and ready to code.
